userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
userStories.tip: Tell those around you what you need...sounds simpler than it is...

userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
userStories.tip: Do as much exercise as you can

userStories.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
userStories.tip: Don't panic-with care and active management you can face the challenge and even go from strength to strength

userStories.question: What’s your best coping strategy?
userStories.tip: Consciously choosing to live positively, acknowledging my disease and actively managing it

userStories.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
Besides medications, what else has worked for you?

condition.description:
Parkinson's disease (PD) is a type of movement disorder. It happens when nerve cells in the brain don't produce enough of a brain chemical called dopamine. Sometimes it is genetic, but most cases do not seem to run in families. Exposure to chemicals in the environment might play a role.

Symptoms begin gradually, often on one side of the body. Later they affect both sides. They include

  • Trembling of hands, arms, legs, jaw and face
  • Stiffness of the arms, legs and trunk
  • Slowness of movement
  • Poor balance and coordination

As symptoms get worse, people with the disease may have trouble walking, talking, or doing simple tasks. They may also have problems such as depression, sleep problems, or trouble chewing, swallowing, or speaking.

There is no lab test for PD, so it can be difficult to diagnose. Doctors use a medical history and a neurological examination to diagnose it.

PD usually begins around age 60, but it can start earlier. It is more common in men than in women. There is no cure for PD. A variety of medicines sometimes help symptoms dramatically. Surgery and deep brain stimulation (DBS) can help severe cases. With DBS, electrodes are surgically implanted in the brain. They send electrical pulses to stimulate the parts of the brain that control movement.

NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
condition.name: Parkinson's disease
symptoms: Trembling of hands, arms, legs, jaw, and face
Stiffness of the arms, legs, and trunk

carousel_items: You should start Pramipexole at a low dose and your doctor will raise the dose slowly. This will help lower your risk of side effects, such as drowsiness and low blood pressure.
Can cause intense urges and compulsive behaviors that are hard to control, such as binge eating, gambling, and sexual urges. Talk to your doctor right away if you have any of these feelings.

You can suddenly fall asleep without warning while on this medicine. Don't perform any tasks that require mental alertness, like driving, or drinking alcohol until you know how Pramipexole affects you. Let your doctor know if you have a history of sleep problems.
Take Pramipexole 2 to 3 hours before bedtime for restless leg syndrome.
Take Pramipexole with food if it makes you feel nauseous.

basics.benefits_moa: Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist. It binds to receptors in the brain and helps improve movement in people with Parkinson's disease or restless leg syndrome.
basics.bottom_line: Pramipexole is an effective medicine for Parkinson's disease or restless leg syndrome, but there are potentially serious side effects.
downsides: Pramipexole isn't a first-choice treatment for Parkinson's disease. It can be used by itself, but it's usually used with other medicines.
Pramipexole can cause hallucinations in older people.
Not the best choice if you have kidney problems. Your doctor may have to adjust your dose based on your kidney function.
You can't suddenly stop taking Pramipexole. You'll have to slowly lower your dose, especially if you've been using it for a long time.

downsides_processed.orig: Pramipexole isn't a first-choice treatment for Parkinson's disease. It can be used by itself, but it's usually used with other medicines.
Pramipexole can cause hallucinations in older people.
Not the best choice if you have kidney problems. Your doctor may have to adjust your dose based on your kidney function.
You can't suddenly stop taking Pramipexole. You'll have to slowly lower your dose, especially if you've been using it for a long time.

upsides: In studies, Pramipexole when taken by itself or with other medicines, was effective in lowering movement fluctuations for people with Parkinson's disease.
Pramipexole is sometimes preferred over other medicines that treat Parkinson's disease in older people since it causes fewer movement and mental fluctuations.
Is effective for treating restless leg syndrome.
Available in a short-acting and a long-acting form.

upsides_processed.orig: In studies, Pramipexole when taken by itself or with other medicines, was effective in lowering movement fluctuations for people with Parkinson's disease.
Pramipexole is sometimes preferred over other medicines that treat Parkinson's disease in older people since it causes fewer movement and mental fluctuations.
Is effective for treating restless leg syndrome.
Available in a short-acting and a long-acting form.

carousel_items_processed.orig: You should start Pramipexole at a low dose and your doctor will raise the dose slowly. This will help lower your risk of side effects, such as drowsiness and low blood pressure.
Can cause intense urges and compulsive behaviors that are hard to control, such as binge eating, gambling, and sexual urges. Talk to your doctor right away if you have any of these feelings.

You can suddenly fall asleep without warning while on this medicine. Don't perform any tasks that require mental alertness, like driving, or drinking alcohol until you know how Pramipexole affects you. Let your doctor know if you have a history of sleep problems.
Take Pramipexole 2 to 3 hours before bedtime for restless leg syndrome.
Take Pramipexole with food if it makes you feel nauseous.

risks_warnings.title: Impulse control problems
risks_warnings.description: Pramipexole can cause intense urges and compulsive behaviors that are hard to control, such as binge eating, gambling, and sexual urges. Talk  to your doctor right away if you have any of these feelings.

description_processed.orig: Pramipexole can cause intense urges and compulsive behaviors that are hard to control, such as binge eating, gambling, and sexual urges. Talk  to your doctor right away if you have any of these feelings.

risks_warnings.title: Driving impairment
risks_warnings.description: Pramipexole lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful and avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.
risk_factors: Taking other medicines that make you less alert

description_processed.orig: Pramipexole lowers your ability to focus, think, and react. Be careful and avoid activities that require you to be alert, such as driving a car or operating machinery, until you know how this medication affects you.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Dizziness can occur due to a sudden drop in blood pressure, especially when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. It's an early side effect of Pramipexole. Typically, the dizziness will go away over time as your body gets used to the medication. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change positions slowly.

description_processed.orig: Dizziness can occur due to a sudden drop in blood pressure, especially when you change positions, such as going from sitting to standing. This is called orthostatic hypotension. It's an early side effect of Pramipexole. Typically, the dizziness will go away over time as your body gets used to the medication. If you're sensitive to low blood pressure, change positions slowly.

risks_warnings.title: Worsening kidney function
risks_warnings.description: Pramipexole is processed by the kidney. If you have kidney problems, talk to your doctor because you may need a different dose.

description_processed.orig: Pramipexole is processed by the kidney. If you have kidney problems, talk to your doctor because you may need a different dose.

risks_warnings.title: Skin cancer
risks_warnings.description: People with Parkinson's disease are at increased risk for melanoma (skin cancer). You may need regular skin examinations while on Pramipexole. Talk to your doctor if you notice anything unusual on your skin.

description_processed.orig: People with Parkinson's disease are at increased risk for melanoma (skin cancer). You may need regular skin examinations while on Pramipexole. Talk to your doctor if you notice anything unusual on your skin.

risks_warnings.title: Hallucinations
risks_warnings.description: Pramipexole can cause hallucinations, especially in older people.

description_processed.orig: Pramipexole can cause hallucinations, especially in older people.

Can cause intense urges and compulsive behaviors that are hard to control, such as binge eating, gambling, and sexual urges. Talk to your doctor right away if you have any of these feelings.

You can suddenly fall asleep without warning while on this medicine. Don't perform any tasks that require mental alertness, like driving, or drinking alcohol until you know how Ropinirole affects you. Let your doctor know if you have a history of sleep problems.
Take Ropinirole 2 to 3 hours before bedtime for restless leg syndrome.
Take Ropinirole with food if it makes you feel nauseous.

basics.benefits_moa: Ropinirole is a dopamine agonist. It binds to receptors in the brain and helps improve movement in people with Parkinson's disease or restless leg syndrome.
basics.bottom_line: Ropinirole is an effective medicine for Parkinson's disease or restless leg syndrome, but there are potentially serious side effects.
downsides: Ropinirole isn't a first-choice treatment for Parkinson's disease. It can be used by itself, but it's usually used with other medicines.
Ropinirole can cause hallucinations in older people.
Not the best choice if you have kidney problems. Your doctor may have to adjust your dose based on your kidney function.
You can't suddenly stop taking Ropinirole. You'll have to slowly lower your dose, especially if you've been using it for a long time.

userStories.tip: Wish I had starteed taking it long ago. I am finally getting a good night's sleep!
I wish I had started taking it long ago!

Take it with some food to avoid nausea.  If your legs have already started twitching, place a tablet under your tongue for faster absorption.  This also helps mitigate possible nausea as it isn't going right into your stomach as a full pill

carousel_items: Take Clozapine exactly as prescribed and don't stop taking it without talking to your doctor.
Can cause dizziness or drowsiness. Avoid alcohol and be careful when changing positions or doing anything that requires your full attention until you know how Clozapine affects you.
Blood tests are needed before you start this medicine and before every refill. You need to pick up the medicine within 7 days of your blood tests.
Can affect your weight, cholesterol, and blood sugar control.

basics.benefits_moa: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic. Researchers don't know exactly how it works. It seems to change dopamine and serotonin activity in your brain, which affects thoughts and mood.
basics.bottom_line: Clozapine treats schizophrenia when other drugs haven't worked, but you'll have to get blood work done regularly and can have weight gain.
downsides: You need to get blood work done every time you can get a prescription filled for Clozapine.
You can only get Clozapine at certain pharmacies that are registered to provide it.
If you don't get Clozapine within 7 days of it being ready at the pharmacy, then you have to get blood work done again and get a new prescription from your doctor.
You need to limit the amount of alcohol you drink while on Clozapine.

downsides_processed.orig: You need to get blood work done every time you can get a prescription filled for Clozapine.
You can only get Clozapine at certain pharmacies that are registered to provide it.
If you don't get Clozapine within 7 days of it being ready at the pharmacy, then you have to get blood work done again and get a new prescription from your doctor.
You need to limit the amount of alcohol you drink while on Clozapine.

upsides: Clinical studies show that Clozapine is effective in treating schizophrenia when other medications have failed.
Has the lowest risk of causing movement problems when compared to other antipsychotic medicines.
Clozapine is available as a normal tablet and as a mint-flavored tablet that dissolves on the tongue without water.

upsides_processed.orig: Clinical studies show that Clozapine is effective in treating schizophrenia when other medications have failed.
Has the lowest risk of causing movement problems when compared to other antipsychotic medicines.
Clozapine is available as a normal tablet and as a mint-flavored tablet that dissolves on the tongue without water.

drugs.one_liner: Helps control your thoughts and actions.
drugs.name: Clozaril

carousel_items_processed.orig: Take Clozapine exactly as prescribed and don't stop taking it without talking to your doctor.
Can cause dizziness or drowsiness. Avoid alcohol and be careful when changing positions or doing anything that requires your full attention until you know how Clozapine affects you.
Blood tests are needed before you start this medicine and before every refill. You need to pick up the medicine within 7 days of your blood tests.
Can affect your weight, cholesterol, and blood sugar control.

risks_warnings.title: Fewer white blood cells
risks_warnings.description: People on Clozapine can lose white blood cells. This makes it harder for the body to fight off infections, and people have died from it. You need to have blood work done every time before your doctor can write a new or refill prescription for Clozapine to make sure you're not at risk.

description_processed.orig: People on Clozapine can lose white blood cells. This makes it harder for the body to fight off infections, and people have died from it. You need to have blood work done every time before your doctor can write a new or refill prescription for Clozapine to make sure you're not at risk.

risks_warnings.title: Low blood pressure | Slow heartbeat | Fainting
risks_warnings.description: You can be at high risk for low blood pressure and a slower heartbeat while on Clozapine, especially if you're on medications for high blood pressure or if you're dehydrated. This can cause fainting and falling if you're not careful. Drink plenty of liquids throughout the day, and talk to your doctor to see if your medications for your blood pressure need to be changed.

description_processed.orig: You can be at high risk for low blood pressure and a slower heartbeat while on Clozapine, especially if you're on medications for high blood pressure or if you're dehydrated. This can cause fainting and falling if you're not careful. Drink plenty of liquids throughout the day, and talk to your doctor to see if your medications for your blood pressure need to be changed.

risks_warnings.title: Seizures
risks_warnings.description: People on Clozapine have reported having seizures. The risk gets higher with increasing dose or if you have conditions that make you more likely to have seizures, like alcohol abuse. If you're on medications because you've had seizures in the past, talk to your doctor to see if the medications need to be adjusted.

description_processed.orig: People on Clozapine have reported having seizures. The risk gets higher with increasing dose or if you have conditions that make you more likely to have seizures, like alcohol abuse. If you're on medications because you've had seizures in the past, talk to your doctor to see if the medications need to be adjusted.

risks_warnings.title: Heart problems
risks_warnings.description: People on Clozapine have had issues with their heart, including swelling of the heart muscles (myocarditis) or other problems with the heart muscles (cardiomyopathy). This can be fatal. Call your doctor immediately if you have chest pain, a fast heartbeat or other problems with your heartbeat, fainting, or flu-like symptoms.

description_processed.orig: People on Clozapine have had issues with their heart, including swelling of the heart muscles (myocarditis) or other problems with the heart muscles (cardiomyopathy). This can be fatal. Call your doctor immediately if you have chest pain, a fast heartbeat or other problems with your heartbeat, fainting, or flu-like symptoms.

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk of death
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of people over 65 years old and who have dementia that have died after taking Clozapine to treat psychiatric problems caused by their dementia.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of people over 65 years old and who have dementia that have died after taking Clozapine to treat psychiatric problems caused by their dementia.

risks_warnings.title: Weight gain
risks_warnings.description: People on Clozapine have reported weight gain. This is common. If this bothers you, talk to your doctor about what you can do to stop this from happening.

description_processed.orig: People on Clozapine have reported weight gain. This is common. If this bothers you, talk to your doctor about what you can do to stop this from happening.

risks_warnings.title: Increased blood sugar
risks_warnings.description: People on Clozapine and have diabetes have reported changes in their blood sugar. Talk to your doctor if you need to change your medications for diabetes.

description_processed.orig: People on Clozapine and have diabetes have reported changes in their blood sugar. Talk to your doctor if you need to change your medications for diabetes.

risks_warnings.title: Increased cholesterol
risks_warnings.description: People on Clozapine have reported increased cholesterol. Talk to your doctor to reduce your risk of heart problems because of increased cholesterol, or if your medications need to be changed if you already have high cholesterol.

description_processed.orig: People on Clozapine have reported increased cholesterol. Talk to your doctor to reduce your risk of heart problems because of increased cholesterol, or if your medications need to be changed if you already have high cholesterol.

risks_warnings.title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS)
risks_warnings.description: There have been reports of people on Clozapine who have had neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which can be fatal. This is very rare, but call your doctor immediately if you notice a high fever, rigid muscles, confusion, an irregular heartbeat, and unusual sweating.

description_processed.orig: There have been reports of people on Clozapine who have had neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which can be fatal. This is very rare, but call your doctor immediately if you notice a high fever, rigid muscles, confusion, an irregular heartbeat, and unusual sweating.

risks_warnings.title: Tardive dyskinesia
risks_warnings.description: People on Clozapine can be more likely to have tardive dyskinesia, which can make you unable to control your movements. This is very rare and can be stopped if you stop taking the medication. If you notice that you can't control your movements, or if you notice shaking or trembling that you can't stop on your own, call your doctor immediately.

description_processed.orig: People on Clozapine can be more likely to have tardive dyskinesia, which can make you unable to control your movements. This is very rare and can be stopped if you stop taking the medication. If you notice that you can't control your movements, or if you notice shaking or trembling that you can't stop on your own, call your doctor immediately.

risks_warnings.title: Return of schizophrenic symptoms
risks_warnings.description: Don't stop taking Clozapine without talking to your doctor, since your symptoms of schizophrenia can come back. You can also have increased sweating, diarrhea, headache, nausea and vomiting. Talk to your doctor if you want to stop taking Clozapine.

description_processed.orig: Don't stop taking Clozapine without talking to your doctor, since your symptoms of schizophrenia can come back. You can also have increased sweating, diarrhea, headache, nausea and vomiting. Talk to your doctor if you want to stop taking Clozapine.

carousel_items: Exelon can cause nausea, vomiting, and dizziness.
Avoid activities that require full mental attention until you know how the drug affects you.
Let your doctor know if you get serious stomach problems, issues with movement (tremor), or weight loss.
If using the patch, make sure you know how to apply it. To prevent skin irritation, change the location of the patch every day.
If using the oral solution, take it after meals to prevent an upset stomach. It can be mixed with cold water, juice, or soda.

clock.tip: Taking with food makes you feel better, but it slows the medication's actions.

basics.benefits_moa: Exelon is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. Researchers don't know exactly how it helps treat Alzheimer's disease, but it prevents acetylcholine, a chemical in the brain, from being broken down too quickly. Acetylcholine is important in transmitting signals through nerves, a process that breaks down in Alzheimer's.
basics.bottom_line: Exelon works for all stages of dementia caused by Alzheimer's, and the oral version is cheaper than the patch.
downsides: Like other medications for dementia, it only slows down the progression of the disease, but it doesn't stop or reverse it.
You need to take the oral capsules twice a day.
The patches are brand name only, so they can be expensive.

downsides_processed.orig: Like other medications for dementia, it only slows down the progression of the disease, but it doesn't stop or reverse it.
You need to take the oral capsules twice a day.
The patches are brand name only, so they can be expensive.

upsides: Can be used to treat dementia caused by all stages of Alzheimer's disease.
Exelon slows the progression of Alzheimer's, including the person's cognitive function and ability to perform the usual daily living activities.
It also improves behavior disorders related to Alzheimer's.
Exelon is available as a patch. This form causes fewer stomach problems (like nausea or vomiting).
The oral capsules are available as a generic medication.

upsides_processed.orig: Can be used to treat dementia caused by all stages of Alzheimer's disease.
Exelon slows the progression of Alzheimer's, including the person's cognitive function and ability to perform the usual daily living activities.
It also improves behavior disorders related to Alzheimer's.
Exelon is available as a patch. This form causes fewer stomach problems (like nausea or vomiting).
The oral capsules are available as a generic medication.

drugs.name: Exelon

carousel_items_processed.orig: Exelon can cause nausea, vomiting, and dizziness.
Avoid activities that require full mental attention until you know how the drug affects you.
Let your doctor know if you get serious stomach problems, issues with movement (tremor), or weight loss.
If using the patch, make sure you know how to apply it. To prevent skin irritation, change the location of the patch every day.
If using the oral solution, take it after meals to prevent an upset stomach. It can be mixed with cold water, juice, or soda.

risks_warnings.title: Nausea and vomiting | Weight loss
risks_warnings.description: People on Exelon have reported nausea and vomiting, decreased appetite and weight loss. This usually happens when the medication is first started and when there are changes in the dose. Talk to your doctor if this is a concern, especially if you have to stop taking the medication for more than 3 days.

description_processed.orig: People on Exelon have reported nausea and vomiting, decreased appetite and weight loss. This usually happens when the medication is first started and when there are changes in the dose. Talk to your doctor if this is a concern, especially if you have to stop taking the medication for more than 3 days.

risks_warnings.title: Skin sensitivity
risks_warnings.description: People on Exelon have reported skin sensitivity and irritation in oral and skin patch forms, but especially with the skin patch. If you notice sensitivity and irritation to your skin, especially around the area where the patch is placed and if it doesn't go away after the patch is removed, talk to your doctor.

description_processed.orig: People on Exelon have reported skin sensitivity and irritation in oral and skin patch forms, but especially with the skin patch. If you notice sensitivity and irritation to your skin, especially around the area where the patch is placed and if it doesn't go away after the patch is removed, talk to your doctor.

risks_warnings.title: Muscle tremors
risks_warnings.description: People on Exelon have reported muscle tremors, especially if they have Parkinson's. Talk to your doctor if this bothers you.

description_processed.orig: People on Exelon have reported muscle tremors, especially if they have Parkinson's. Talk to your doctor if this bothers you.

risks_warnings.title: Ulcers | Bleeding in the stomach
risks_warnings.description: People on Exelon have reported stomach ulcers which can also lead to bleeding in the stomach and intestines. Taking medications for inflammation, such as NSAIDs (ibuprofen or naproxen), can make this worse. Talk to your doctor if you vomit blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, or if your stool has blood or looks black and tarry. You can help prevent this by having some food or milk in your stomach when you take the oral medication.

description_processed.orig: People on Exelon have reported stomach ulcers which can also lead to bleeding in the stomach and intestines. Taking medications for inflammation, such as NSAIDs (ibuprofen or naproxen), can make this worse. Talk to your doctor if you vomit blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, or if your stool has blood or looks black and tarry. You can help prevent this by having some food or milk in your stomach when you take the oral medication.

surveys.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
surveys.tip: Tell those around you what you need...sounds simpler than it is...

surveys.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
surveys.tip: Do as much exercise as you can

surveys.question: What tip would you give someone like me who was just diagnosed?
surveys.tip: Don't panic-with care and active management you can face the challenge and even go from strength to strength

surveys.question: What’s your best coping strategy?
surveys.tip: Consciously choosing to live positively, acknowledging my disease and actively managing it

surveys.question: Besides medications, what else has worked for you?
